A week after his arrival, Essex held a great feast for St George’s Day, during which he bestowed no less than 38 knighthoods. In a proclamation issued in October, the queen declared the 38 titles void, see CSPI 1599–1600, 218.
title: The most famous account of the episode is in Camden who reports that after falling over who should be appointed Lord Deputy of Ireland, “she was impatient, gave him a cuffe on the eare, and bade hime be gone with a vengeance. He layed his hand upon his sword, the Lord Admirall interposing himself, hee sware a great oath, that he neither could nor would swallow so great an indignitie, nor would have borne it at King Henry the 8 his hands; and in great discontentment hasted from the Court,” William Camden, The History of the Most Renowned and Victorious Princesse Elizabeth

Essex’s ceremonial departure cheered by the crowds in the streets of London and accompanied by very strange weather, is recorded in John Stow’s Annales ( John Stow, The Annales of England, Faithfully Collected out of the Most Autenticall Authors

160. Ballads and prayers were written for the occasion (the most popular being Thomas Churchyard’s “Fortunate Farwell to the Most Forward and Noble Earl of Essex”) and William Shakespeare famously recorded Essex’s departure, and the hope he would come back with “rebellion broached on his sword
